title: Who are your people when systems fail?
teaser: Institutions are collapsing. Networks are transactional. So when it all falls apart, who actually stays?
framework: Matthew 6:33 - Seek first the kingdom... and all these things will be added

panels.heading: THE INSTITUTIONS ARE FAILING
panels.content:
Your government can't agree on basic governance. 71% of people are dissatisfied with how democracy is working. Political violence is rising. Trust in institutions is at historic lows.

Your workplace is collapsing into itself. Mass layoffs, quiet firing, job insecurity. The company that promised career security just eliminated your department.

Your community is fragmenting. Churches are declining. Civic organizations are dying. The places people used to gather—gone or empty.

Everything that was supposed to hold you together is coming apart.

So when the systems fail, who do you turn to?

panels.heading: THE TRANSACTIONAL NETWORKS
panels.content:
You thought you had people.

Your network is full. LinkedIn connections, social media followers, work friends, college acquaintances.

But here's the truth: **most of those relationships are transactional.**

They're there when you're useful. When you can help their career. When you're fun at parties. When you're winning.

But when you lose your job? Silence.
When you're struggling? They're busy.
When you need actual help? Suddenly unavailable.

Because networks aren't built for crisis. They're built for exchange.

And when you have nothing left to trade, the network disappears.

panels.heading: THE COST OF SHALLOW CONNECTIONS
panels.content:
The cost of living in transactional networks is this: **you're surrounded by people but deeply alone.**

29% of Americans report being frequently lonely. You have 500 friends online and no one to call at 2 a.m. You're in group chats that go silent when you share anything real.

You thought connection was about accumulation—more followers, more contacts, more reach.

But you're learning the hard way: **quantity isn't community.**

When the crisis hits—when you lose your job, when your mental health collapses, when your family falls apart—your network scatters.

Because they were never your people. They were your contacts.

And contacts don't stay when systems fail.

illustration.description: Dithered image of crowded room with isolated figure, or network graph with broken connections

panels.heading: THE ANCIENT QUESTION
panels.content:
There's an ancient story about this.

2,000 years ago, in the middle of imperial Rome's collapsing systems—political violence, economic exploitation, religious corruption—a question emerged:

**Who are your people when empire fails?**

The answer wasn't the state. It wasn't the temple. It wasn't the marketplace.

It was something else. Something countercultural and subversive.

A carpenter-turned-teacher named Jesus began forming small gatherings. Not networks. Not institutions. Something deeper.

Communities bound by covenant, not transaction.

People who stayed when everything fell apart.

And in a fracturing world, they became the answer to the question:

**These are your people.**

panels.heading: THE DIFFERENT KIND OF BELONGING
panels.content:
Jesus didn't build a network. He built a family.

Not biological. Not transactional. Covenantal.

The early followers of Jesus didn't just meet for services. They shared meals, resources, lives. When persecution came, they didn't scatter—they hid together. When poverty hit, they pooled funds. When empire crushed them, they carried each other.

**They were bound by something stronger than utility.**

They belonged to each other because they first belonged to God.

And that kind of belonging doesn't evaporate when you stop being useful.

It's the difference between a network and a covenant.

One scatters. The other remains.

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

I'm surrounded by people but I'm alone. My network is full but shallow. When I needed real help, everyone scattered.

I'm tired of transactional connections. I'm tired of performing to stay valuable.

You say there's a different kind of belonging. Covenant, not contract. People who stay, not just when I'm useful.

Show me what that looks like.

Who are my people when systems fail?

I need to know.

Amen.
